Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funds for students, postdocs, and junior researchers to participate in a "Workshop on Interdisciplinary Mathematics" to be held on May 8-10, 2015, at the Department of Mathematics, Penn State University. Applied mathematics in the modern world faces the challenges of developing new mathematical techniques and approaches to help advance research in other disciplines. A goal of this workshop is to help prepare the future generation of applied mathematicians to face these challenges. It will also help to establish new contacts and create long-term relationships between research groups at different institutions in the US and in Europe. All the plenary speakers invited at the workshop are internationally well established researchers and leaders in their fields. The talks are expected to be of an expository nature, not technical, but of a high scientific level.

The primary audience of the workshop will consist of graduate students and young researchers. During the three days of the conference, nine plenary speakers will deliver widely accessible survey talks. These talks will cover a broad spectrum of applications: materials science, biology and medicine, complex fluids, and finance. In addition, there will be a round table discussion on new directions, where analytical and computational techniques could provide novel insights. Together with local graduate students, postdocs, and junior faculty, 12-15 young researchers will be invited from other institutions, covering their travel and local expenses. All participants will have an opportunity to present their work in poster sessions. Some of them, selected by the organizers, will also give short talks. The web site for the Workshop is https://www.math.psu.edu/cim/events/workshops-2015-may-8.html

POR.DRECONTENT:
Mathematics in the modern world  becomes increasingly  interdisciplinary as it faces the challenges of developing new mathematical techniques  to  help advance research in other   fields of science. The main goal of "Workshop on Interdisciplinary Mathematics” was to help  prepare the future generation of applied mathematicians to face these challenges. The workshop took place at the Genetti Hotel in Williamsport, Pennsylvania and brought together an impressive collection of the leading experts  as well as junior researchers (over 40 participants) from different countries.  Each specializing in diverse areas of interdisciplinary mathematics to advance the importance of  mathematics in other scientific disciplines  (such as materials science, physics, biology, medicine, and finance). The Scientific/Organizing Committee consisting of Leonid Berlyand (Penn State University), Alberto Bressan (Penn State University), and Suncica Canic (University of Houston) selected plenary speakers and invited a large number of junior participants.

 The workshop also  aided in establishing new contacts and creating potential long-term relationships between research groups at institutions from all over the U.S.  and  Europe.   All the plenary speakers invited to the workshop are internationally well established researchers, and leaders in their own field. The invited plenary  talks  were  of expository nature, i.e. not technical, but of a high scientific level so as to be accessible to everyone in attendance including the primary  audience of the workshop: graduate students and young researchers.  During the three days of the workshop, these nine plenary speakers covered a broad spectrum of  applications: materials science, physics, biology, medicine, and finance.  The organizers ensured that there was additional time built into the schedule for young researchers  who delivered short talks and  poster presentations.   One of the major outcomes of this workshop was the number of discussions that took place concerning new directions where  analytical and computational techniques  could provide novel insights highlighting the future of interdisciplinary mathematics.
